Mediahater

Official Documentation‚Äã

Mediahater is a lightweight, extensible messaging pipeline for .NET developers ‚Äî built to give you full control over request/response dispatching, fire-and-forget notifications, and middleware composition.

After releasing SwizzleV, StatePulse.NET, and CoreMap, it felt natural to close my release spree with a clearly Licensed, MediatR alternative.

No janky license games & No lock-in.

Just a sharp tool under the forever MIT License.

‚ú® What You Get‚Äã

  • Request Handling
    • Void requests (commands)
    • Response-producing requests (commands/queries)
  • Notification Publishing
    • Fire-and-forget messages
    • Multiple handlers per notification
  • Middleware Pipelines
    • Request middlewares (IRequestMiddleware)
    • Notification middlewares (IPublisherMiddleware)
  • Decouple
  • True-Minimal dependencies
  • No licensing drama

üß≠ Why Medihater?‚Äã

Some packages start simple but over time get tangled in fuzzy licensing, dual-licenses, or quiet EULA shifts.
Medihater is here to be:

  • Transparent ‚Äî MIT now, MIT forever
  • Simple ‚Äî One purpose: in-process message handling

If you're already using SwizzleV, StatePulse, or CoreMap, this fits right in a natural continuation as pipelines.

üß≠ What's Next?‚Äã

  • SenderMiddleware
  • Abstracted Cacher (Cacher could be replaced)
  • Improved Performance (Still some areas we could improve)
  • Implement IMedihatR -> Features a Request Prepper/Notification Prepper with cool features like StatePulse.NET.

‚ö†Ô∏è My Issues with Mediator (as of 2025-07-17)‚Äã

Mediator advertises ‚Äúzero dependencies‚Äù. Reality check:

  • Microsoft.Bcl.AsyncInterfaces (>= 8.0.0)
  • Microsoft.Extensions.DependencyInjection.Abstractions (>= 8.0.0)
  • Microsoft.Extensions.Logging (>= 8.0.0)
  • Microsoft.IdentityModel.JsonWebTokens (>= 8.0.1)

There is nothing wrong with depending on packages, but don‚Äôt claim zero-dependencies.
For something that should be a simple, unambitious mediator, this feels pretty ambitious when paired with confusing licensing, it‚Äôs a red flag for long-term projects.

‚ùì Why not use MediatR fork?‚Äã

There are already well-known mediator packages out there ‚Äî some powerful, some battle-tested. I won't try to convince you that Mediahater does something magical you couldn't write yourself in few lines of code.

But here's the thing:

It felt right to round off the stack with a clean, reliable messaging system ‚Äî one thing I know for certain:

There will be none of team lead tapping me on the shoulder saying: ‚ÄúHey... this package isn't free anymore. We need to stop updating or start migrating.‚Äù

That‚Äôs the entire point of Mediahater.

It‚Äôs not trying to outdo the giants. It‚Äôs here because sometimes, trust and control matter more than hype.

If you're already using SwizzleV or StatePulse, this is the missing glue ‚Äî familiar, safe, and yours to build on without second-guessing.

üôå Contributions Welcome‚Äã

Feel free to open issues, suggest improvements, or submit pull requests. If you like it, star it.
